Author: Kazuhisa Hirao
Review: It's quite a distance from Uji Station, and when you pass through the stone main gate, Kotozaka with a total length of 200m awaits you. On the first Sunday in October, the Uji Tea Festival is held in the main hall, where the tea jar opening ceremony and tea offering ceremony are held, and at the tea whisk mound, a memorial service for the tea whisk is held. In the Shoin, the tea ceremony held by the sponsor is held, so you can see the inside of the hall and the garden.

Remains of Fushimi Castle (blood-stained ceiling, tsumugi-bari corridor)

Keihan Uji Line: 1.1 km from Uji Station.

Review:
Koshoji-san is a hidden little-known spot, Kotozaka autumn leaves
It's a sight to see, the large parking lot is free ^ _ ^
Those who wish can also visit, it is 300 yen ^ _ ^ ^

Koshoji is a temple of the Soto sect in Uji City, Kyoto Prefecture. It is the first Soto sect temple in Japan. It started when Dogen built Koshohorinji Temple. After being discontinued, it was revived by Naomasa Nagai in 1648. The mountain name is Mt. Buttoku. The principal object of worship is Shaka Sanzon. The approach to the shrine is called 'Kotozaka' and is counted as one of the Twelve Views of Uji.

In the garden, up to the upper 4th level of the floating island thirteen-storied pagoda
be.

Author: ÂíåÁî∞ÂêâÂºò
Review:
I was introduced to it by a person I met at work, and I've been interested in Zen meditation (reservation required 1000 yen).
What is Zazen? After a brief instruction, I enter zazen. There is no such thing as hitting the back with.
You will be invited to a space for zazen, and you will sit cross-legged with a certain distance from the wall (sitting with a zabu for zazen under your buttocks), so you will sit for a long time. not.
In fact I did two 15 minute sessions (with a break in between). My legs were already numb after the first session, but the chief priest who instructed me walked out of the meditation space and took me outside for a break. He was very kind.
Sit cross-legged, correct your posture, open your eyes
just sit.
It was midsummer early in the morning when I went for the experience, so I was very impressed by the wind blowing through the zazen space and the chirping of cicadas.
The beauty of the mountain path leading to the temple, the atmosphere of the temple, and the simple but self-reflecting time spent in Zen meditation were very important to me.
When I do zazen, I worry about my posture.
I wasn't interested in temples or religion at all, but I would like to go back to Koshoji, which I visited for the Zen meditation experience.

In the summer, the walking path to Amagase Suspension Bridge, which is about 2km one way, is surrounded by green roofs and feels very cool.
Return the way you came, and if you have time, you can walk for about 30 minutes to the Mt.
Also, during the autumn foliage season, you can enjoy the foliage at the best little-known spot where you can visit Koshoji Temple in Uji when it is less popular, such as early in the morning or on weekdays.
However, the parking lot is closed during the fall foliage season, so it is better to park in the free public parking lot 500 meters away and take a walk.

Author: go ao
Review:
This is the first Soto sect temple built by Dogen Daishi.
Because he was frugal and thrifty, he was worried that Uji would be strongly influenced by the politics and gaudiness of the capital, so he moved to Eiheiji Temple in Fukui.
There is Kotozaka where autumn leaves are beautiful, but due to the typhoon last year, there were many fallen trees. The number has decreased, but Unsui-san and others of the temple are trying to protect the existing autumn leaves.

Author: ÂÆÖË¶ãËÇá
Review:
Founded in 1233 by Dogen Zenji, the founder of the Soto sect, this training dojo was first opened in 1649. The current building was rebuilt in 1649.

12/10 Entrance fee 500 yen.
The slope leading to the temple gate is called Kotozaka because the sound of water running on both sides sounds like the sound of a koto. The white temple gate of Ryugu-zukuri comes into view. Just dive in, change into the slippers at the entrance, and follow the regular route.

starting in the kitchen. Before long, we arrive at the sanctuary, which uses the remains of Fushimi Castle to create a bloody ceiling, a corridor covered in warblers to detect the dangers of outside intruders, and the principal image of Buddha Shakyamuni.
The courtyard is well maintained to accommodate the number of worshipers.

See the golden statue of Kannon Bodhisattva in the Treasure Hall, the statue of Naomasa Nagai in the Tenjikuden, and the seated statue of Dogen Zenji in the Kaizando.

The mountain gardens in front of and behind the Kaizando are small but splendid, and the flower chozubachi (hand-washing basin) is gorgeous at this time of year.
Finally, it ends at the statue hall where the trainee monks sit in meditation.

You can also experience Zen meditation and sutra copying, so you might be able to meet such a handsome monk...

After all, photos are generous, whatever you want!
Oh yeah, there was a photo that looked like me at the photo exhibition, so I put it in (laughs)‚úåÔ∏è

Author: „Åã„Åå„Åø„ÄÇ
Review:
I found out that I could experience a participatory art project, so I went there on the evening of December 5th.
I arrived at around 5:30 pm, but there was a line for the art project experience, so I went around the temple first.
Although it was nighttime, the monks were chanting sutras, so when I was looking at them for a while, a passing monk said, "If you don't mind, please sit down."
Even after looking around and coming back, the line for the experience did not break, so I lined up for about 15 minutes to experience it.
While we were queuing, there were two people who explained the experience to us.
Even though it was very cold, the waiting time didn't take long, thank you *¬∞
In the experience, when you hold up a QR code, you can see images of flowers and dandelion fluff flying at your feet.
I took a picture, but I regretted that I should have taken a video.
I went for this experience and the autumn leaves, but I felt that the autumn leaves came a little late.
I would like to see the scenery in the daytime, so I would like to come again if I have the opportunity.

Author: Sao sound
Review:
I'm so sad to miss you.
When I looked at the map, I suddenly became interested in this place.
I have been guided by the pictures of the Buddhas here from famous places. I feel a gentle atmosphere.
When I arrived, I was irritated because the car was forced to pass on a narrow uphill. Then come to the entrance and hah! will do. Everything was looked straight at the principal image.
Embarrassing.

I paid 500 yen to meet the Kannon inside.
A half-hearted presence when facing to the right.
I was wondering if I should go to my knees. i wanna go.
I thought I was going to buy a bill, so I sat down on Kannon's lap.

Then strangely
Just as I was about to put in the money, I leaned forward and it felt like Kannon was stroking my head. üò≥
Since it's 300 yen, I don't think I noticed it at the speed of putting in 3 100-yen coins.
Until now, I was embarrassed and shy in front of Kannon, but I cried.
Normally, it is rare to see Kannon from such a close distance. Even if you put 10,000 yen in it, you won't regret it.

After being comforted by Kannon for a while, I realized my essence this time. Because I didn't trust him.
Over and over again I was canceled at the last minute and became distrustful.
I can no longer trust people.
It seems that I just paid for it, and there was no one around,
It was good just to realize that.
That's what you're saying.

By the way, you can meditate on the tatami mats in the garden.
just take a deep breath
Serotonin and oxytocin are released perfectly.
After that, I went to Ujigami Shrine, but it didn't fit. I definitely recommend this temple. and go alone.
I think it's okay to go with friends or for sightseeing, but it's hard to get to the best places.

Author: ÊùæÊæ§ÈõÖ‰∏Ä
Review:
It is a temple descended from the first temple built in Japan's Soto sect.
At first, it was in Fukakusa, Fushimi, but the Soto sect at that time could not withstand the impeachment from the new religion and existing sects in the Kamakura period, so it was closed.
It was rebuilt at its current location.

The uphill that continues from the first gate is a famous place for autumn leaves, and it extends straight.
When you go up the slope, there is another temple gate and you will be in the precincts.
There is an automatic ticket vending machine that sells admission fees and goshuin stamps in front of the temple gate (anti-infection measures?).

If you walk straight, there is a corridor and there is a notice board to go to the right.
Take off your shoes (slippers are provided) and go to the reception.
At the reception, check the ticket issued by the ticket vending machine (if you want to receive a goshuin, leave the goshuin book).
First of all, you will be urged to the main hall.
The ceiling is a bloody ceiling.
It's the floorboards of Fushimi Castle when it fell.
One aspect of the training dojo is similar to Eiheiji Temple in Fukui, which is the Soto sect.

The nearest station is Uji Station, but if you come from Kyoto Station, take JR.
If you are coming from the city areas of Osaka or Kyoto, is it Keihan?
Directions from the Keihan station are easier to understand.
Cross the pedestrian crossing in front of the station and walk along the Uji River in the direction of Ujigami Shrine. After passing Ujigami Shrine, walk for about 5 minutes and you will see the Sakashita Gate.

Author: mihoko F
Review:

Author: Joe Cool
Review:
2022.10.29 (Sat) I want to see the phoenix of Byodo-in Temple and visit Uji for the second time in my life
The staff at the tourist information center at Keihan Uji Station told me that Koshoji Temple is one of the power spots, so I decided to ask!

After enjoying Byodo-in Temple, head to Koshoji Temple along the Uji River under the clear autumn sky.
On the way to Kotozaka, I was overwhelmed by the powerful flow of water flowing into the Uji River from a tributary of the Kanryu Bridge.

The main hall has a bloody ceiling that is said to have been relocated from Fushimi Castle, and you can clearly see the handprints and footprints.
It's quite far from the city center, so it's a quiet and solemn atmosphere, a relaxing place. I definitely felt like I had power.

Review:
This temple is famous for the autumn leaves of Kotozaka.
It has the same name as the first temple of the Japanese Soto sect, with more than 14,000 temples, the largest number of temples in Japan as a single religious temple. This is the branch temple of Eiheiji Temple, which was rebuilt as a family temple by Naomasa Nagai, the lord of the Yodo domain, by relocating the building of Fushimi Castle.

There is a parking lot in front of the mountain gate that climbed Kotozaka, and during the season, pedestrians were given priority and traffic was restricted, so please be aware that you will be walking at other tourist spots and using paid parking lots along the way.

Fujiwara culture such as Byodo-in Temple and Ujigami Shrine and "Zazen" may be too different.

Author: Êùë‰∏äÈ°ï
Review: Zen garden inside. But I like the approach. The autumn foliage on both sides that burn bright red in the fall is astonishing. This is the key that foreigners know well.

Author: Yuchuva
Review:
I visited twice during the fall foliage season.
Koshoji Temple is famous for Kotozaka, and the tunnel of bright red autumn leaves is beautiful.
Since it is the first dojo of Zen and Soto sects to open, events such as monthly zazen sessions are actively held.

Vending machines can be used to buy worship tickets, but discount coupons are sometimes distributed at restaurants around Uji, so if you want to use them, you need to go to the indoor reception.

The highlights are the statue of Sho Kannon, also known as Tenarai Kannon, and the three-faced Daikokuten, which is Hideyoshi's principal deity to protect his success in life. There is also a place where you can relax and enjoy the view of the garden, so it is recommended for a leisurely trip.

Author: Aji Saba
Review: Cross the Uji River from Byodo-in Temple and you will find it at the end of the autumnal slopes. There are not many autumn leaves in the precincts, and it is a quiet place where you can take a break after climbing the slope. It seems that they are also doing light up, but the scale is... passed.

Author: Akino Shiori
Review: From the Ryumon along the Uji River, go up Kotozaka, an approach known for its autumn leaves, to reach the Sanmon. The area around the temple is surrounded by a fence, and many temples are built in the precincts. It is Dogen Zenji's first dojo and the oldest training dojo of the Soto sect. Currently, the general public is also accepting experiences of Zen meditation and sutra copying. The temples are connected by a corridor, so you can visit them in a round trip. In the center of the precincts, there is a large, well-maintained garden with pine trees and pagodas. There were few people visiting and I was able to visit slowly.

Author: ekasit wasanasiriwan
Review: It's a very small temple with many worship rooms to be seen. In the main hall has a small and beautiful garden. We went on 31st December, there was only our group.

Review: I was very grateful for the consideration of preparing a chair and a throw in the place where I could see the garden.

Author: Naho
Review:
This is the first dojo of Dogen Zenji, the founder of the Soto sect.
The atmosphere of the mini Eiheiji temple was also wonderful. I was overwhelmed by the authenticity and solemnity of the monastery.
There was a three-faced Daikokuten.
The famous Kotozaka and the sound of the water are like the sounds of bells, and I felt that I understood a little of how Dogen Zenji decided to set up a training hall in this area. (Actually, it seems to have been moved from Fukakusa, but...)

Author: „Ç´„É®„É®
Review:
This is my favorite temple.
I felt that everything was well taken care of.
It is a ticket vending machine system. Admission fee and Goshuin.
The lady at the reception was very nice and explained everything in detail. The principal image is not big, but it has a gentle, calm and refreshing expression.
The flower chozubachi is also cute, and the outdoor Buddha statue has a nice expression, and I want to see you again.
I bought a bell with the tone of Suikinkutsu. You can choose from about 8 colors.

Author: Heidi
Review: Quite a small and new temple compared to other temples and places in Uji. It is a Zen temple with lots of worship room. If you are planning to visit Koshoji, you have to pick autumn season because the Kotozaka (the way to Koshoji) will look amazing!

Author: Brian Lin
Review: Gorgeous fall colors.

Author: Maki
Review:
A Zen temple of the Soto sect founded by Dogen in 1233.
You can experience Zen meditation and sutra copying.
The slope up to the temple gate is called Kotozaka, and the sound of the water flowing through the waterways on both sides is said to sound like the sound of a koto. The autumn leaves make a tunnel, and it will be dyed bright red in autumn.

Author: Ben Hsu
Review:
Koushouji Temple in Uji has been traditionally translated as "Koshoji" Temple in English, although the Temple itself uses Koushouji Temple for its web site and for its email communications.

While the Temple is a Buddhist Temple with history, the Temple is also famous for its funeral religious services to the decreased families. For the Temple itself, it has beautiful garden and gold-plated decorations hanging from ceilings of the main worship hall.

Koushouji Temple is suitable for the visitors, who visit Byodoin Temple in the same Uji area, for the short walking distance, although on the opposite side of the Uji River.

Author: Chris F
Review: One of the best temples I have been to

Author: H LULU
Review: I practiced Zazen. The explanation about Buddhism was easy to understand, and I felt refreshed after sitting meditation.

Author: Ëûç‰∫å‰∏≠Â∑ù
Review: It's about a 10-minute walk from Byodo-in Temple, and I went from Tachibana Bridge via Asagiri Bridge. Go through Buttokuyama Ryumon, go through Kotozaka and enter from the Sanmon gate. It was a small temple, and it was rare to be able to take pictures inside. (Other than Buddha can be photographed.) There was also a small garden around several temples such as Daishoin, Law Hall, etc., and it was beautifully maintained.

Author: Yuichi Maeda
Review: From the time I entered, I was kindly asked to take photos freely.I felt beautiful and clean inside. The garden was also very beautiful.

Author: R.Y
Review: I've been to Uji many times, but this was the first time I'd been to a temple here, but the Kotozaka slope from the temple gate and the inside of the temple were really nice.
